TEXT.citation: Early, R. J., & Whitehorn, J. (2003). One hundred Paiwan texts. Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University.
TEXT.BibTeX_citation: @book{100paiwantexts, author = {Robert Early and John Whitehorn}, title = {One Hundred Paiwan Texts}, year = {2003}, publisher = {Pacific Linguistics, Research School of Pacific and Asian Studies, The Australian National University}}

S.FORM: tiamen a se Payuan nu lima tsavił a małevuq.
tiamen a se Payoan no lima cavilj a maljevoq.
S.TRANSL: We Paiwans hold a festival every five years.

S.FORM: a patagił malang tua qapuḍung katua vuluq.
a patagilj malang toa qapodrong katoa voloq.
S.TRANSL: We begin by making a ball and spears.

S.FORM: qau ita qiłas a kipalak.
qao ita qiljas a kipalak.
S.TRANSL: We practise for one month.

S.FORM: nu itanga a qiłas, sema tjua mamazangiłan a małevuq.
no itanga a qiljas, sema tjoa mamazangiljan a maljevoq.
S.TRANSL: After the month we go to the chief to hold the festival,

S.FORM: katsuin a vuluq katua qapuḍung.
kacoin a voloq katoa qapodrong.
S.TRANSL: taking the spears and the ball.

S.FORM: qau seman tsakar i likuz tua tsatsavał.
qao seman cakar i likoz toa cacavalj.
S.TRANSL: We make a ceremonial platform behind the village gate.

S.FORM: pitju a qadaw i likuz tua tsatsavał.
pitjo a qadaw i likoz toa cacavalj.
S.TRANSL: It is seven days behind the gate.

S.FORM: qau sema tjai qayaw anga tua tsatsavał, malang tauta tua tsakar.
qao sema tjai qayaw anga toa cacavalj, malang taota toa cakar.
S.TRANSL: Then we come in front of the gate and make another platform.

S.FORM: tuazua qadaw a vavayan seman qavay seman vava.
toazoa qadaw a vavayan seman qavay seman vava.
S.TRANSL: That day the women make dumplings and beer.

S.FORM: nu tjelu anga a qadaw zemiazian a ḍusa a qadaw.
no tjelo anga a qadaw zemiazian a drosa a qadaw.
S.TRANSL: Every three days we dance for two days (or After three days we dance for two days).

S.FORM: kenvava, qemapuḍupuḍung anga i tjai qayaw i tsatsavał.
kenvava, qemapodropodrong anga i tjai qayaw i cacavalj.
S.TRANSL: We drink and play the ball game in front of the gate.

S.FORM: avan anga tuazua qemaqivu tua vuvu.
avan anga toazoa qemaqivo toa vovo.
S.TRANSL: And that’s when we summon our grandparents,

S.FORM: qau pakan anga tua qavay tua vava.
qao pakan anga toa qavay toa vava.
S.TRANSL: and give them dumplings and beer.

S.FORM: semenay anga mapułat.
semenay anga mapoljat.
S.TRANSL: We all sing.

S.FORM: avan a łapiłapi qinałan a mamazangiłan katua puqenetj a tsautsau a sipatjanema a ngadan nu semenay.
avan a ljapiljapi qinaljan a mamazangiljan katoa poqenetj a caocao a sipatjanema a ngadan no semenay.
S.TRANSL: When we sing, it’s the chiefs of neighbouring villages and the famous people whose names we mention.

S.FORM: kemasi tsuay azua a pinatagił.
kemasi coay azoa a pinatagilj.
S.TRANSL: This began long ago.

S.FORM: nu lima a qadaw qematsuvung; vaik a qemałup.
no lima a qadaw qemacovong; vaik a qemaljop.
S.TRANSL: We finish after five days, and go and hunt.

S.FORM: nu mangtjez a naqemałup, a tsuru nua vuluq alangen.
no mangtjez a naqemaljop, a coro noa voloq alangen.
S.TRANSL: When we come back from hunting, we make tips for our spears.

S.FORM: qau vaik a sema itjua vutu a maqinatsap.
qao vaik a sema itjoa voto a maqinacap.
S.TRANSL: And we go to enemy areas to hunt heads.

S.FORM: nu qemtsi, katsuin a qulu; qau maleva.
no qemci, kacoin a qolo; qao maleva.
S.TRANSL: When we kill someone, we bring the head back and celebrate.

S.FORM: nu mangtjez i tjumaq, maqepu; qau seman qała sema tjua mamazangiłan.
no mangtjez i tjomaq, maqepo; qao seman qalja sema tjoa mamazangiljan.
S.TRANSL: When we get home, people gather, and we celebrate victory over the enemy at the chief’s place.

S.FORM: qau zemian: "nanguaq a tja tsavił."
qao zemian: "nangoaq a tja cavilj."
S.TRANSL: We dance to celebrate: “It’s a good year for us.”

S.FORM: a uqałay vavayan kakeḍian mapułat maqepu sema tjua mamazangiłan.
a oqaljay vavayan kakedrian mapoljat maqepo sema tjoa mamazangiljan.
S.TRANSL: Men, women and children all gather at the chief’s place.

S.FORM: a naqemtsi a tsautsau kematsu tua ḍiḍi, tu sipakan tua qintsi.
a naqemci a caocao kemaco toa dridri, to sipakan toa qinci.
S.TRANSL: The person who made the kill brings a pig, to feed the person killed.

S.FORM: qau zemiazian, saka qemauqauqaw a malevaleva tua qintsian.
qao zemiazian, saka qemaoqaoqaw a malevaleva toa qincian.
S.TRANSL: And we dance, and shout to celebrate the killing.

S.FORM: a qulu nua qintsi pinivetsekadan tua katsasavan a pinivavaw tua valanga.
a qolo noa qinci pinivecekadan toa kacasavan a pinivavaw toa valanga.
S.TRANSL: The head of the person killed is put in the middle of the courtyard on a mortar,

S.FORM: qau uqałay vavayan kakeḍian kipalingulinguł a zemian.
qao oqaljay vavayan kakedrian kipalingolingolj a zemian.
S.TRANSL: and men, women and children dance round it.

S.FORM: nu lima a qadaw puamin anga; sitjanga qałaqała.
no lima a qadaw poamin anga; sitjanga qaljaqalja.
S.TRANSL: We finish after five days. We have treated the dead like a guest (?).

S.FORM: qau puamin anga.
qao poamin anga.
S.TRANSL: That’s the end.
